item.title: Enum Tutorial, Need criticsm to make this better
item.dc:creator: @matzie matzie
item.description:
@matzie wrote:

nvm about last post XD forgot i changed it. It is only 2 different exceptions now, LoginProtocolException, and LoginCancelationException. The first one logs, the second one doesnt.

[code]public class LoginProtocolException extends RuntimeException {

    public LoginProtocolException(String error, String... args) {
        Logger.getLogger(ConnectionHandler.class.getName()).logp(Level.WARNING, "ConnectionHandler", "Connect", error, args);

    }
}

[/code][code]

public class LoginCancelationException extends RuntimeException {
}[/code]

but the format i had was similiar to java.awt.geom types.

Read full topic
item.source: Enum Tutorial, Need criticsm to make this better

item.title: Enum Tutorial, Need criticsm to make this better
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“matzie, post:18, topic:537903”][quote author=Pure_ link=topic=656727.msg4419010#msg4419010 date=1397495362]

[quote author=matzie link=topic=656727.msg4418772#msg4418772 date=1397366313]

Ryley is right. I am also using enums for all client toggles. http://pastebin.com/2GxgZPq2 no flame please. Ima noob.

[quote]/*******************************************************************************

  • [Constants.java] Constants are variables with values that can’t be changed.
  • The value is assigned to a constant when it is declared. Constants are used
  • to give names to certain values so that their meaning is more obvious. The
  • meaning of the number 3.14 is not obvious but if it was given the name PI
  • then you know immediately what it means. Use the word final in front of a
  • normal variable declaration to make it a constant. It is also highly advised
  • to use ALL_CAPS name to declare the variables. Our method is also to put them
  • in enumerations. This way, it is more organized.
  • @author Artem Batutin(artembatutin@gmail.com)
  • @version 7
  • Copyright © Avarrocka LTD. 2014 - Avarrocka Client Development.
    ******************************************************************************/[/quote]
    I see this and i ask you, why make this in your constants class?

Personally, for the login errors. i made it throw an error for it.
if (ERROR SHOULD BE THROWN)
throw new RuntimeExceptions.EXCEPTION_NAME();

[code=java5]public final class RuntimeExceptions {
public static class Invalid_Credentials extends RuntimeException {
public Invalid_Credentials(String name, String ip) {
super(String.format(“Invalid login attempt: %s from: %s”,name,ip));

        }
}
public static class Invalid_Username extends RuntimeException {
        public Invalid_Username(String name, String ip) {
            super(String.format("Unknown user %s from %s",name,ip));
            
        }
}

}
[/code]
just have a try-catch block for them and you have a safe way to exit your login protocol as well (: i don’t know how this would work with IOSession though, i use this for a straight through connect
catch (EXCEPTION_NAME ex) {
//log it?
//write return code
//close session
}

I use runtimeexceptions because they dont “have” to be caught, but now that i think of it you probably should it make it so they have to be.
[/quote]I would keep them in separate classes, like how the official language does it.
[/quote]Yea, but then you has another package in your IDE floating around :\ There’s enough in there already IMO. I did it this way with them all being in a LoginException class. So I can organize them that way.[/quote]Doesn’t change the fact that it’s atrocious.

Read full topic
item.source: Enum Tutorial, Need criticsm to make this better

item.description:

[quote=“matzie, post:14, topic:537903”][quote author=artem543 link=topic=656727.msg4400609#msg4400609 date=1390533312]
Ryley is right. I am also using enums for all client toggles. http://pastebin.com/2GxgZPq2 no flame please. Ima noob.
[/quote]

[quote]/*******************************************************************************

  • [Constants.java] Constants are variables with values that can’t be changed.
  • The value is assigned to a constant when it is declared. Constants are used
  • to give names to certain values so that their meaning is more obvious. The
  • meaning of the number 3.14 is not obvious but if it was given the name PI
  • then you know immediately what it means. Use the word final in front of a
  • normal variable declaration to make it a constant. It is also highly advised
  • to use ALL_CAPS name to declare the variables. Our method is also to put them
  • in enumerations. This way, it is more organized.
  • @author Artem Batutin(artembatutin@gmail.com)
  • @version 7
  • Copyright © Avarrocka LTD. 2014 - Avarrocka Client Development.
    ******************************************************************************/[/quote]
    I see this and i ask you, why make this in your constants class?

Personally, for the login errors. i made it throw an error for it.
if (ERROR SHOULD BE THROWN)
throw new RuntimeExceptions.EXCEPTION_NAME();

[code=java5]public final class RuntimeExceptions {
public static class Invalid_Credentials extends RuntimeException {
public Invalid_Credentials(String name, String ip) {
super(String.format(“Invalid login attempt: %s from: %s”,name,ip));

        }
}
public static class Invalid_Username extends RuntimeException {
        public Invalid_Username(String name, String ip) {
            super(String.format("Unknown user %s from %s",name,ip));
            
        }
}

}
[/code]
just have a try-catch block for them and you have a safe way to exit your login protocol as well (: i don’t know how this would work with IOSession though, i use this for a straight through connect
catch (EXCEPTION_NAME ex) {
//log it?
//write return code
//close session
}

I use runtimeexceptions because they dont “have” to be caught, but now that i think of it you probably should it make it so they have to be.[/quote]I would keep them in separate classes, like how the official language does it.

item.title: Enum Tutorial, Need criticsm to make this better
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

using an enum to hold constants is pretty horrible design

what if you want some constants to be a String type or other constants to be a long type or int type? that isn’t going to work very well with an enum

artem543:

Ryley is right. I am also using enums for all client toggles. http://pastebin.com/2GxgZPq2 no flame please. Ima noob.

/******************************************************************************* * [Constants.java] Constants are variables with values that can't be changed. * The value is assigned to a constant when it is declared. Constants are used * to give names to certain values so that their meaning is more obvious. The * meaning of the number 3.14 is not obvious but if it was given the name PI * then you know immediately what it means. Use the word final in front of a * normal variable declaration to make it a constant. It is also highly advised * to use ALL_CAPS name to declare the variables. Our method is also to put them * in enumerations. This way, it is more organized. * * @author Artem Batutin(artembatutin@gmail.com) * @version 7 * * Copyright (c) Avarrocka LTD. 2014 - Avarrocka Client Development. ******************************************************************************/
I see this and i ask you, why make this in your constants class?

Personally, for the login errors. i made it throw an error for it.
if (ERROR SHOULD BE THROWN)
throw new RuntimeExceptions.EXCEPTION_NAME();

[code=java5]public final class RuntimeExceptions {
public static class Invalid_Credentials extends RuntimeException {
public Invalid_Credentials(String name, String ip) {
super(String.format(“Invalid login attempt: %s from: %s”,name,ip));

}

just have a try-catch block for them and you have a safe way to exit your login protocol as well (: i don’t know how this would work with IOSession though, i use this for a straight through connect

item.title: Enum Tutorial, Need criticsm to make this better
item.dc:creator: @strucker Strucker
item.description:
@strucker wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:10, topic:537903”]you’re forgetting a ton

enums can implement interfaces
enum constants can override methods
… so on

also stop doing things in the constructor… that’s bad practice… the constructor is used to construct the class, not do your dirty work
also stop documenting shit that doesn’t need documented

like this:

/** * the "this" keyword is used to access variables that are out * of our method, and as we have the same name on the logId * If i did logId = logId;, it would do nothing, so with the "this" * keyword, i access the variable I've declared before the constructor * * So what does it does? * it makes the variable logId(the one we declared right before * making this constructor) the same value the constant has * so now we can access our values in the constant */

and this:

/** * great, we've completed an enum!, now to access the values in * it we need help from our loved for loop, we are gonna make a method * to check if the number put as a parameter matches the logid. */[/quote]Can i have examples on those so i can add them to the tutorial, i wasnt aware they could override. btw i commented that much because i wanted anyone to understand it even if he didnt know too much.

Read full topic

enums can implement interfaces

… so on

also stop doing things in the constructor… that’s bad practice… the constructor is used to construct the class, not do your dirty work
also stop documenting shit that doesn’t need documented

like this:

/** * the "this" keyword is used to access variables that are out * of our method, and as we have the same name on the logId * If i did logId = logId;, it would do nothing, so with the "this" * keyword, i access the variable I've declared before the constructor * * So what does it does? * it makes the variable logId(the one we declared right before * making this constructor) the same value the constant has * so now we can access our values in the constant */

and this:

/** * great, we've completed an enum!, now to access the values in * it we need help from our loved for loop, we are gonna make a method * to check if the number put as a parameter matches the logid. */

item.source: Enum Tutorial, Need criticsm to make this better

item.title: Enum Tutorial, Need criticsm to make this better
item.dc:creator: @strucker Strucker
item.description:
@strucker wrote:

[code=java]/**
*

  • @author Arthur, Strucker, Mr Boogie…
  •     well now im gonna try to explain how to use enums I'll have an

  •     example with firemaking first, It's the easier skill so you'd better

  •     understand.

*/
public class Enums {

/**
 * well first of all we gotta do an enum, to do it we write the keyword
 * enum, after that, we type the name of the enum The conventions tell us to
 * do something different on the naming that on normal methods, the naming
 * on enums, is UpperCase that means that the first letter should be
 * capital.
 */
private enum LogData {
	
	/**
	 * then we gotta declare your constant/s, as I've said 
	 * a constant is final and static, and a constant is always typed
	 * in CAPITAL_LETTERS and to separate words we use an underscore
	 * 
	 * @param 1521
	 * 		it means the log id, the constructor will be defined below, as you keep reading
	 * 		you will understand what the 1521 means
	 */
	NORMAL(1521);
	
	/**
	 * now we need a variable to retrieve the value/s that will
	 * be stored in our constant, so I'll define it as logId
	 * 
	 * @param logId
	 * 		the id of the log that is going to be lit.
	 */
	private int logId;
	
	/**
	 * great, now we have to define wich parameters our constants have
	 * to take, for now it only takes a log, wich is our 1521, in our normal constant
	 * the 1521 number is the item index of the normal log
	 */
	private LogData(int logId) {
		
		/**
		 * the "this" keyword is used to access variables that are out
		 * of our method, and as we have the same name on the logId
		 * If i did logId = logId;, it would do nothing, so with the "this"
		 * keyword, i access the variable I've declared before the constructor
		 * 
		 * So what does it does?
		 * it makes the variable logId(the one we declared right before 
		 * making this constructor) the same value the constant has
		 * so now we can access our values in the constant
		 */
		this.logId = logId;
	}
	
	/**
	 * returns the id of the log
	 */
	private int getLog() {
		return logId;
	}
}

/**
 * great, we've completed an enum!, now to access the values in
 * it we need help from our loved for loop, we are gonna make a method
 * to check if the number put as a parameter matches the logid.
 */

/**
 * 
 * @param log
 *		this method receives a parameter to be comparised with the
 *		values in the enum
 */
private void comparison(int log) {
	/**
	 * Now to access the data in our enum we have to do a for loop
	 * to do it we type for( then the enum name, then the keyword to access it(You
	 * pick it, (i picked e.) then two dots ":", and then again the enum name but 
	 * right after the last letter we type .values(), then we close the for ) and open a bracket..
	 */
	for(LogData e: LogData.values()) {
		
		/**
		 * Now we are gonna check if the parameter matches a log id
		 */
		if(log == e.getLog()) {
			System.out.println("That number is a log!");
		} else if(log != e.getLog()) {
			System.out.println("This is embarrasing, seems like that isn't a log");
		}
	}
}

private Enums() {
	
	try {
		
	/**
	 * first it will check if the number 1 is an actual log
	 */
	comparison(1);
	
	/**
	 * after that will check if the numer 500 is an actual log
	 */
	comparison(500);
	
	/**
	 * Then we pause 2 seconds before the next check
	 */
	Thread.sleep(2000);
	
	/**
	 * After we waited 2 seconds, we check if 1521 is a log..
	 */
	comparison(1521);
	
	} catch (Exception e){
		
	}
}

/**
 * execute the program..
 */
public static void main(String args []) {
	Enums e = new Enums();
}

/**
 * And the output was...
 * This is embarrasing, seems like that isn't a log
 * This is embarrasing, seems like that isn't a log
 * That number is a log!
 */

}[/code]

Read full topic
item.source: Enum Tutorial, Need criticsm to make this better
